text: A quadratic equation ax^2 + bx + c = 0 has roots (-b ± sqrt(b^2 - 4ac)) / (2a).
Completing the square rewrites ax^2 + bx + c into a(x + b/2a)^2 + (4ac - b^2)/4a.
The derivative of sin x is cos x; of cos x is -sin x.
The derivative of e^x is e^x; of ln x is 1/x for x>0.
The product rule: (fg)' = f'g + fg'. The chain rule: (f∘g)' = (f'∘g)·g'.
The definite integral accumulates signed area; Fundamental Theorem: ∫_a^b f = F(b) - F(a).
Mean ≥ Median ≥ Mode for right-skewed distributions; reversed for left-skewed.
Variance is the mean of squared deviations from the mean; std dev is its square root.
A vector space requires closure, associativity, identity, inverses, distributivity, and scalar compatibility.
The dot product a·b = |a||b|cosθ; it’s maximal when vectors align.
A matrix is invertible iff det(A) ≠ 0 and columns are linearly independent.
Rank of a matrix equals the dimension of its column space.
Eigenvalues λ satisfy det(A - λI) = 0; eigenvectors solve (A - λI)v = 0.
The gradient ∇f points in the direction of steepest ascent.
A convex function’s epigraph is a convex set; local minima are global.
Bayes’ rule: P(A|B) = P(B|A)P(A)/P(B).
The central limit theorem: sums of i.i.d. variables approach normality.
L1 regularization promotes sparsity; L2 shrinks weights smoothly.
Logistic function σ(x) = 1/(1+e^{-x}) maps ℝ to (0,1).
Softmax converts scores to probabilities via exp and normalization.
Cauchy–Schwarz inequality: |a·b| ≤ ||a||·||b|| with equality for colinear vectors.
Triangle inequality: ||a + b|| ≤ ||a|| + ||b||.
Probability mass functions sum to 1; densities integrate to 1.
The expected value is linear: E[aX + bY] = aE[X] + bE[Y].
Covariance measures joint variability; correlation is normalized covariance.
The harmonic mean is appropriate for rates; geometric mean for growth factors.
A sequence converges if it approaches a finite limit as n→∞.
Taylor series approximates smooth functions near a point via derivatives.
A basis of a vector space is a linearly independent spanning set.
LU decomposition factors A into lower and upper triangular matrices.
Newton’s 2nd law: F = m·a; momentum p = m·v; impulse changes momentum.
Work W = ∫ F·dx; kinetic energy K = ½mv^2; potential energy depends on position.
Power is the rate of doing work: P = dW/dt; for electricity, P = VI.
Ohm’s law: V = IR; series resistances add, parallel add via reciprocals.
Capacitive reactance X_C = 1/(ωC); inductive reactance X_L = ωL.
In AC, RMS voltage V_rms = V_peak/√2 for sine waves.
Snell’s law: n1 sin θ1 = n2 sin θ2; refraction bends toward higher n.
Thermodynamics: ΔU = Q − W; entropy tends to increase in isolated systems.
Blackbody radiation follows Planck’s law; peak wavelength ~ 1/T (Wien’s).
Wave speed v = fλ; Doppler shift changes observed frequency with relative motion.
Photoelectric effect: electrons emitted when photon energy exceeds work function.
Uncertainty principle: Δx·Δp ≥ ħ/2; measurement disturbs conjugate variables.
Big-O gives an upper bound on growth; common classes: O(1), O(log n), O(n), O(n log n), O(n^2).
Binary search requires a sorted array and runs in O(log n).
Quicksort average time O(n log n), worst-case O(n^2); randomized pivot mitigates worst-case.
Merge sort guarantees O(n log n) and is stable; needs additional memory.
A hash table provides expected O(1) insert/lookup with a good hash and resizing.
A heap supports O(log n) push/pop; a binary heap is array-backed.
A graph can be represented by adjacency lists (sparse) or matrix (dense).
Dijkstra finds single-source shortest paths on non-negative weights.
Bellman–Ford handles negative edges; Floyd–Warshall finds all-pairs shortest paths.
DFS is good for topological sort; BFS finds shortest paths in unweighted graphs.
Union–Find (DSU) supports near-constant amortized merges with path compression.
Dynamic programming solves overlapping subproblems via memoization or tabulation.
Greedy algorithms make locally optimal choices; correctness requires matroid/greedy-choice property.
Trie stores strings character by character; useful for prefix queries and autocomplete.
AVL/Red–Black trees maintain O(log n) operations via balancing.
Bloom filters are space-efficient with false positives but no false negatives.
LRU cache evicts least-recently-used entries to bound memory.
Backtracking explores choices depth-first and prunes on constraints.
Normalization reduces redundancy: 1NF (atomic), 2NF (no partial deps), 3NF (no transitive deps).
Primary keys uniquely identify rows; foreign keys enforce referential integrity.
Indexes speed reads but slow writes; choose columns used in WHERE/JOIN.
Use EXPLAIN to inspect query plans and find bottlenecks.
Avoid SELECT * in production; select only needed columns to reduce I/O.
Transactions ensure ACID: atomicity, consistency, isolation, durability.
In OLAP, star schemas with fact and dimension tables support analytics.
Use parameterized queries or ORM bindings to prevent SQL injection.
TCP provides reliable, ordered delivery; UDP is connectionless and faster but unreliable.
TLS uses asymmetric crypto to exchange a symmetric session key securely.
DNS resolves names to IP addresses; caching reduces lookup latency.
CIDR notation a.b.c.d/24 gives a prefix length of 24 bits for the network.
HTTP/2 multiplexes streams over one TCP connection; HTTP/3 uses QUIC over UDP.
Latency matters more than bandwidth for small requests; reduce round trips.
Processes have isolated memory; threads share address space within a process.
Context switches are costly; use async I/O to avoid blocking on waits.
Mutexes ensure mutual exclusion; deadlocks require circular wait among resources.
Virtual memory maps pages to physical frames; TLB caches translations.
Bias–variance tradeoff: overly simple models underfit; overly complex models overfit.
Train/validation/test splits help estimate generalization; avoid leakage.
Cross-entropy is standard for classification; MSE for regression.
Class imbalance requires metrics beyond accuracy (F1, AUROC, PR AUC).
Regularization (L1/L2/dropout) controls overfitting by constraining weights.
Early stopping halts training when validation loss stops improving.
Gradient descent updates parameters opposite the gradient of loss.
Batch normalization stabilizes training by normalizing activations.
Transformers use self-attention to model long-range dependencies.
Word embeddings map words to vectors capturing semantic similarity.
k-NN classifies by majority vote among nearest neighbors; choice of k matters.
Confusion matrix summarizes TP, FP, TN, FN; precision vs recall trade off.
REST uses stateless HTTP with resources identified by URLs; use proper status codes.
Idempotent methods (GET, PUT, DELETE) can be retried safely; POST is not idempotent.
JWTs carry claims; sign (HS/RS) and set short expiry; store refresh tokens securely.
CORS controls which origins can access resources; preflight for complex requests.
Content Delivery Networks cache static assets near users to reduce latency.
Docker images are built in layers; keep them small by minimizing packages.
Containers are ephemeral; persist data via volumes or external stores.
Kubernetes orchestrates containers; Deployment manages replicas and rollouts.
CI/CD automates build, test, deploy; small, frequent releases reduce risk.
Feature flags decouple deploy from release; allow gradual rollouts.
AC current changes polarity and magnitude over time; DC keeps constant polarity.
Kirchhoff’s laws: current into a node equals current out; loop voltages sum to zero.
pH is −log10[H+]; each unit is a tenfold change in acidity.
Le Chatelier’s principle: a system shifts to oppose imposed changes.
DNA stores genetic information as sequences of nucleotides A, T, C, G.
Mitochondria produce ATP via oxidative phosphorylation in the electron transport chain.
Supply and demand intersect at equilibrium price and quantity.
Opportunity cost is the value of the next best alternative forgone.
SMART goals are Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound.
Pomodoro technique uses short focused sprints with regular breaks to boost productivity.
